Use block elaborate filtering achieved simple value selection, numeric comparisons, calculations, complex logical conditions. Combine multiple conditions using & () require conditions true, | () require least one condition true. expression editor provides syntax highlighting validates expressions. title: blockr.dplyr Showcase: Data Wrangling Blocks
text: slice block selects specific rows based different criteria. Choose six slice types: head (first rows), tail (last rows), min (rows smallest values), max (rows largest values), sample (random selection), custom (specific positions). head tail types, specify number rows using n (count) prop (proportion 0 1). min max types, select order_by column enable with_ties want include rows tied values. sample type, optionally select weight_by column weighted sampling enable replace sampling replacement. custom type accepts rows expression like “1:5” “c(1, 3, 5, 10)”. slice types support grouping via parameter, performs slice operation within group separately. Slice block interface

title: blockr.dplyr Showcase: Data Wrangling Blocks
text: mutate expression block creates new columns modifies existing ones using R expressions. Add multiple expressions, creating updating column. expression consists column name R expression calculates value. Use mathematical operators (+, -, *, /, ^) functions (sqrt(), log(), round(), etc.) expressions. Reference existing columns name. can also use conditional logic ifelse() dplyr::case_when(). Expression order matters: later expressions can reference columns created earlier expressions mutate block. parameter allows grouping, making column references operate within group. Add expressions “+ Add Expression” button remove “×” button. Mutate expression block interface

Remove rename operation “×” button. block validates don’t rename column twice ensures column names don’t conflict existing names. Rename block interface

title: blockr.dplyr Showcase: Data Wrangling Blocks
text: summarize block calculates summary statistics using point--click interface. summary consists three parts: name new column, aggregation function selected dropdown, column aggregate. Available aggregation functions include mean, sum, minimum, maximum, count, count distinct, median, standard deviation, . Select function dropdown column apply . Use “Columns group ” selector group data summarizing. grouping enabled, statistics calculated separately group. title: blockr.dplyr Showcase: Data Wrangling Blocks
text: summarize expression block calculates summary statistics using R expressions. Use block elaborate aggregations require custom expressions, weighted means, ratios, functions specific parameters. Enter expressions like mean(mpg), sum(hp), dplyr::n(), complex calculations like mean(mpg, na.rm = TRUE) sum(hp) / dplyr::n(). expression editor provides syntax highlighting autocomplete (Ctrl+Space). Use “Columns group ” selector group data summarizing. “Show advanced options” section provides additional settings like unpack option handling functions return data frames. Summarize expression block interface

title: blockr.dplyr Showcase: Data Wrangling Blocks
text: join block combines two datasets based matching values specified columns. Select six join types determine rows kept result. Join types: left_join keeps rows left dataset matching rows right; right_join keeps rows right dataset matching rows left; inner_join keeps rows match datasets; full_join keeps rows datasets; semi_join filters left dataset rows match right; anti_join filters left dataset rows match right. “Custom Column Mappings” interface supports -name joins (columns identical names) different-name joins (matching columns different names dataset). Add multiple join keys match multiple columns simultaneously. Enable “Use natural join” automatically join common columns. Join block interface

Columns input dataset placed next output. input datasets must exactly number rows. rows combined position: first row dataset forms first row output, second rows form second row output, . datasets columns name, automatically renamed numeric suffixes (e.g., “Sepal.Length…1”, “Sepal.Length…6”) avoid conflicts.
